repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Economic Management Capacity
            Building Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Economic Management
            Capacity Building Project for Ghana were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was moderate; Bank performance was unsatisfactory;
            and borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned includes: this was overlooked when the
            PSR and the FSR programs were combined. Cross-sector
            approach could work if there is synergy: e.g. government
            debt management in public sector reform (e.g. forecasting,
            planning and cash management) and domestic bond market
            development in financial sector reform. The institutional
            capacity of the Bank's managing unit, as well as of the
            client and the implementing agencies, has to be considered
            when determining how wide a sector-wide approach should be.
            Given the open-endedness of the PSR program in the design
            phase, it appears an adaptable or more phased-in instrument
            will be more fitting. There was only one QER close to the
            decision meeting for appraisal and project negotiation. It
            appears that before the project was submitted for Board
            review, the design was not checked to see if the QER and
            decision meeting recommendations were incorporated. The
            financial sector part of the project benefited from strong
            ownership of the reform strategy by the Government of Ghana
            (GOG) and the regulatory authorities, thanks to the
            participatory approach in years of Financial Sector
            Strategic Plan (FINSSP) development. The regular Financial
            Sector Assessment Program (FSAP) updates (2003, 2006 and
            2011) gave the Bank a handle on the status of Ghana's
            financial sector.

repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Economic Management Capacity
            Building Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Economic Management
            Capacity Building Project for Ghana is to support the
            Recipient to perform its role as a facilitator for economic
            development through: strengthening of the governance and
            competitiveness of the financial sector. The closing date
            for the project will be extended from June 30, 2011 until
            December 30, 2012. The extension is necessary to support the
            completion of select financial sector reform activities,
            facilitate the transition to Second Financial Sector
            Strategy Plan (FINSSP II) and begin the implementation of
            reform measures arising from the joint World
            Bank-International Monetary Fund (IMF) Financial Sector
            Assessment (FSA) carried out in 2010. A dedicated work plan
            has been devised to this end. This will be the first
            extension of the project.

display_title.display_title:
Ghana - Economic Management
            Capacity Building Project : restructuring : Main report

repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Economic Management Capacity
            Building Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Economic Management
            Capacity Building Project for Ghana is to support the
            recipient to perform its role as a facilitator for economic
            development through: (i) implementation by Ministries,
            Departments, and Agencies (MDAs) of a reform initiative for
            improved public sector management and service delivery; and
            (ii) strengthening of the governance and competitiveness of
            the financial sector. This paper seeks approval from the
            Country Director for a second-order restructuring plan for
            the project based on the results of the midterm review
            conducted in August 2009, and the slower than anticipated
            implementation pace thereafter. The restructuring will allow
            refocusing the activities on outstanding priorities, and
            improving overall project implementation performance. The
            closing date of the project, originally set for June 30,
            2011, will be extended by 18 months, until December 30, 2012.

display_title.display_title:
Ghana - Economic Management
            Capacity Building Project : restructuring : Main report
